subject: Art
title: Weight & Style
description: How bold, light, italic, and condensed variations create a type system.

hook.text: A typeface family is like a wardrobe: Light for whispers, Regular for conversation, Bold for emphasis, Black for shouting. Italic for asides. Condensed for tight spaces. Each weight and style has a voice.

buildup.text: Common weights: Thin, Light, Regular, Medium, SemiBold, Bold, ExtraBold, Black. Common styles: Roman (upright), Italic (angled, often redesigned letterforms), Oblique (mechanically slanted). Width: Condensed, Normal, Extended.

discovery.text: Weight creates hierarchy: Bold headings, Regular body, Light captions. Using one typeface family in multiple weights is often more cohesive than mixing multiple typeface families. Variety within unity.

twist.text: True italics are redesigned letterforms (notice the 'a' changes shape in many fonts). Obliques are just slanted versions of the roman. The difference is subtle but reveals the care the type designer invested.

climax.text: Build a page using only ONE typeface family: Black for the headline, Bold for subheads, Regular for body, Light for captions, Italic for quotes. The result is harmonious and hierarchical ‚Äî no font clashing.

punchline.text: One family, many voices. Weight and style create variety within harmony.

quiz.question: What is a true italic, as opposed to an oblique?
options: A mechanically slanted version of the roman
Redesigned letterforms specifically drawn for an angled style
